title: Cape Hatteras National Seashore: Photos & Multimedia
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     Photos & Multimedia             Photos & Multimedia         Sunset at Cape Hatteras National Seashore National Park Service  Photography and Cape Hatteras go hand-in-hand. Miles of Atlantic Ocean coastline, sandy barrier islands, and the Pamlico and Roanoke Sounds all work in concert to provide environments ideal for capturing the stunning beauty of nature or the plethora of recreational opportunities enjoyed by visitors.           We have included some of our favorite photographs of the places, activities, and people of the seashore in the following galleries. Cape Hatteras National Seashore also has an official Flickr site (CapeHatterasNPS), which you can follow to keep up with new sights and events from the seashore as we add to our photograph collection.                   Scenery   16 Photos  View the scenic beauty of Cape Hatteras National Seashore.          Recreational Activities   6 Photos  See various ways to enjoy Cape Hatteras National Seashore.          Ocracoke Ponies   15 Photos  If you want to adopt a specific pony, you can see their pictures here.            Sea Turtles   4 Photos  Look at sea turtles and associated resource management activities.          Birds   44 Photos  Images of just a few of the birds that visit Cape Hatteras National Seashore.          Mammals   2 Photos  Photographs of some of the mammals found within Cape Hatteras National Seashore.            Plants   35 Photos  Some plants found in the various ecosystems of Cape Hatteras National Seashore.          Light Stations   37 Photos  Views of the three light stations found within Cape Hatteras National Seashore.          Moving the Cape Hatteras Light Station   25 Photos  In 1999, the entire Cape Hatteras Light Station was moved 2,900 feet to the southwest.            Hammock Hills Nature Trail   2 Photos  Views along the Hammock Hills Nature Trail on Ocracoke Island.          Young Naturalists   14 Photos  The Cape Hatteras Young Naturalists learn about dunes during the first day of Spring 2014.
